#!/bin/bash
# SC-2: Application Partitioning
# Verify kernel ASLR is enabled
echo "Checking ASLR configuration..."
sysctl kernel.randomize_va_space
if [ "$(sysctl -n kernel.randomize_va_space)" != "2" ]; then
    echo "Enabling full ASLR..."
    sysctl -w kernel.randomize_va_space=2
    echo "kernel.randomize_va_space = 2" >> /etc/sysctl.d/99-security.conf
fi

# Verify SELinux is enforcing
echo "Checking SELinux status..."
getenforce
if [ "$(getenforce)" != "Enforcing" ]; then
    echo "WARNING: SELinux not in enforcing mode"
fi
linux.ansible:
---
- name: SC-2 Application Partitioning
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Enable ASLR
      sysctl:
        name: kernel.randomize_va_space
        value: '2'
        state: present
        sysctl_file: /etc/sysctl.d/99-security.conf
        reload: yes

    - name: Verify SELinux is enforcing
      selinux:
        policy: targeted
        state: enforcing

windows.powershell:
# SC-2: Application Partitioning
# Verify DEP (Data Execution Prevention) is enabled
$dep = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_OperatingSystem | Select-Object DataExecutionPrevention_SupportPolicy
Write-Host "DEP Policy: $($dep.DataExecutionPrevention_SupportPolicy)"

# Verify ASLR through Windows Defender Exploit Guard
Get-ProcessMitigation -System | Select-Object ASLR
windows.ansible:
---
- name: SC-2 Application Partitioning - Windows
  hosts: windows
  tasks:
    - name: Enable DEP via registry
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Memory Management
        name: EnableCfg
        data: 1
        type: dword

1. Implement access controls: Ensure that only authorized users have access to shared system resources. Use role-based access control (RBAC) to restrict access based on user roles and responsibilities.
2. Encrypt data: Use encryption techniques to protect sensitive information when it is being transferred or stored on shared system resources.
3. Regularly monitor and audit access: Keep track of who is accessing shared system resources and what actions they are performing. Regularly review access logs and audit trails to detect any unauthorized activities.
4. Train employees: Provide training to employees on the importance of protecting information in shared system resources and the potential risks of unauthorized information transfer.
5. Implement data loss prevention (DLP) tools: Use DLP tools to monitor and prevent the unauthorized transfer of sensitive information through shared system resources.
6. Regularly update and patch systems: Ensure that all systems hosting shared resources are up to date with the latest security patches to prevent vulnerabilities that could be exploited for unauthorized information transfer.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-5: Denial of Service Protection
echo "Configuring DoS protections..."

# Enable SYN cookies
sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies=1
echo "net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies = 1" >> /etc/sysctl.d/99-dos-protection.conf

# Limit connection tracking
sysctl -w net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max=1000000
echo "net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max = 1000000" >> /etc/sysctl.d/99-dos-protection.conf

# Configure iptables rate limiting
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --syn -m limit --limit 1/s --limit-burst 3 -j ACCEPT
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --syn -j DROP

# Install and configure fail2ban
if ! command -v fail2ban-client &> /dev/null; then
    yum install -y fail2ban || apt-get install -y fail2ban
fi
systemctl enable fail2ban
systemctl start fail2ban
linux.ansible:
---
- name: SC-5 Denial of Service Protection
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Enable SYN cookies
      sysctl:
        name: net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies
        value: '1'
        state: present
        reload: yes

    - name: Set connection tracking limit
      sysctl:
        name: net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max
        value: '1000000'
        state: present
        reload: yes

    - name: Install fail2ban
      package:
        name: fail2ban
        state: present

    - name: Enable fail2ban service
      service:
        name: fail2ban
        state: started
        enabled: yes

windows.powershell:
# SC-5: Denial of Service Protection
# Configure Windows Firewall rate limiting
$ruleName = "DoS-Protection-Rate-Limit"

# Enable Windows Firewall
Set-NetFirewallProfile -Profile Domain,Public,Private -Enabled True

# Configure TCP settings to mitigate SYN flood
netsh int tcp set global maxsynretransmissions=2

# Enable SYN attack protection
Set-ItemProperty -Path "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters" -Name "SynAttackProtect" -Value 1
Set-ItemProperty -Path "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters" -Name "TcpMaxPortsExhausted" -Value 5

Write-Host "DoS protection configured"
windows.ansible:
---
- name: SC-5 DoS Protection - Windows
  hosts: windows
  tasks:
    - name: Enable Windows Firewall
      win_firewall:
        state: enabled
        profiles:
          - Domain
          - Private
          - Public

    - name: Configure SYN attack protection
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters
        name: SynAttackProtect
        data: 1
        type: dword

#!/bin/bash
# SC-7: Boundary Protection
echo "Configuring firewall boundary protection..."

# Ensure firewalld is installed and running
systemctl enable firewalld
systemctl start firewalld

# Set default zone to drop
firewall-cmd --set-default-zone=drop

# Allow only necessary services
firewall-cmd --permanent --add-service=ssh
firewall-cmd --permanent --add-service=https

# Enable logging of denied packets
firewall-cmd --permanent --set-log-denied=all

# Reload firewall
firewall-cmd --reload

# Display current configuration
echo "Current firewall configuration:"
firewall-cmd --list-all
linux.ansible:
---
- name: SC-7 Boundary Protection
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Ensure firewalld is installed
      package:
        name: firewalld
        state: present

    - name: Start and enable firewalld
      service:
        name: firewalld
        state: started
        enabled: yes

    - name: Set default zone to drop
      firewalld:
        zone: drop
        state: enabled
        permanent: yes
        immediate: yes

# SC-8: Transmission Confidentiality and Integrity
# Configure TLS settings

# Disable weak protocols
$protocols = @("SSL 2.0", "SSL 3.0", "TLS 1.0", "TLS 1.1")
foreach ($protocol in $protocols) {
    $serverPath = "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Protocols\$protocol\Server"

    Set-ItemProperty -Path $serverPath -Name "Enabled" -Value 0

    Set-ItemProperty -Path $clientPath -Name "Enabled" -Value 0
    Set-ItemProperty -Path $clientPath -Name "DisabledByDefault" -Value 1

# Enable TLS 1.2

$tls12Client = "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\SCHANNEL\Protocols\TLS 1.2\Client"

#!/bin/bash
# SC-10: Network Disconnect
echo "Configuring session timeout..."

# Set TMOUT for bash sessions (15 minutes = 900 seconds)
echo "TMOUT=900" >> /etc/profile.d/timeout.sh
echo "readonly TMOUT" >> /etc/profile.d/timeout.sh
echo "export TMOUT" >> /etc/profile.d/timeout.sh

# Configure SSH timeout
cat >> /etc/ssh/sshd_config << 'EOF'
# SC-10 Session Timeout
ClientAliveInterval 300
ClientAliveCountMax 0
EOF

systemctl restart sshd

echo "Session timeout configured to 15 minutes"
linux.ansible:
---
- name: SC-10 Network Disconnect
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Set TMOUT in profile
      copy:
        dest: /etc/profile.d/timeout.sh
        content: |
          TMOUT=900
          readonly TMOUT
          export TMOUT
        mode: '0644'

    - name: Configure SSH ClientAliveInterval
      lineinfile:
        path: /etc/ssh/sshd_config
        regexp: '^ClientAliveInterval'
        line: 'ClientAliveInterval 300'
      notify: restart sshd

    - name: Configure SSH ClientAliveCountMax
      lineinfile:
        path: /etc/ssh/sshd_config
        regexp: '^ClientAliveCountMax'
        line: 'ClientAliveCountMax 0'
      notify: restart sshd

    - name: restart sshd

        name: sshd
        state: restarted

#!/bin/bash
# SC-13: Cryptographic Protection (FIPS)
echo "Checking FIPS mode status..."

# Check if FIPS mode is enabled
if [ -f /proc/sys/crypto/fips_enabled ]; then
    fips_status=$(cat /proc/sys/crypto/fips_enabled)
    if [ "$fips_status" == "1" ]; then
        echo "FIPS mode is ENABLED"
    else
        echo "FIPS mode is DISABLED"
        echo "To enable FIPS mode, run: fips-mode-setup --enable"
    fi
else
    echo "FIPS support not available in kernel"
fi

# Verify OpenSSL FIPS
openssl version
openssl list -providers 2>/dev/null || openssl list-cipher-algorithms | head -10

      changed_when: false
      failed_when: false

linux.bash:
#!/bin/bash
# SC-28: Protection of Information at Rest
echo "Checking disk encryption status..."

# Check for LUKS encrypted volumes
lsblk -f | grep -i luks
if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
    echo "WARNING: No LUKS encrypted volumes detected"
    echo "To encrypt a volume, use: cryptsetup luksFormat /dev/sdX"
fi

# Check swap encryption
swapon -s
cat /etc/crypttab | grep swap

# Verify dm-crypt module
lsmod | grep dm_crypt

echo "Encryption status check complete"
linux.ansible:
---
- name: SC-28 Protection of Information at Rest
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Ensure dm-crypt module is loaded
      modprobe:
        name: dm_crypt
        state: present

    - name: Check for encrypted volumes
      command: lsblk -f
      register: block_devices
      changed_when: false

    - name: Display encryption status
      debug:
        var: block_devices.stdout_lines

    - name: Install cryptsetup
      package:
        name: cryptsetup
        state: present

windows.powershell:
# SC-28: Protection of Information at Rest
# Check and enable BitLocker

# Check BitLocker status
$bitlockerStatus = Get-BitLockerVolume -MountPoint "C:"

if ($bitlockerStatus.ProtectionStatus -eq "On") {
    Write-Host "BitLocker is ENABLED on C:"
    Write-Host "Encryption Method: $($bitlockerStatus.EncryptionMethod)"
} else {
    Write-Host "BitLocker is NOT enabled on C:"
    Write-Host "To enable BitLocker, run:"
    Write-Host "Enable-BitLocker -MountPoint 'C:' -EncryptionMethod XtsAes256 -UsedSpaceOnly -RecoveryPasswordProtector"
}

# List all BitLocker volumes
Get-BitLockerVolume | Format-Table MountPoint, VolumeStatus, EncryptionPercentage, ProtectionStatus
windows.ansible:
---
- name: SC-28 Protection of Information at Rest - Windows
  hosts: windows
  tasks:
    - name: Check BitLocker status
      win_shell: |
        Get-BitLockerVolume -MountPoint "C:" | Select-Object ProtectionStatus
      register: bitlocker_status

    - name: Enable BitLocker if not enabled
      win_shell: |
        Enable-BitLocker -MountPoint "C:" -EncryptionMethod XtsAes256 -UsedSpaceOnly -RecoveryPasswordProtector
      when: "'Off' in bitlocker_status.stdout"

intent: To prevent unauthorized data exfiltration, malware introduction, and hardware-based attacks by controlling physical port and I/O device access on systems that process, store, or transmit sensitive information.
rationale: Physical ports such as USB, FireWire, Thunderbolt, and SD card slots represent significant attack vectors. Malicious actors can use removable media to exfiltrate data, introduce malware, or install unauthorized hardware keystroke loggers. Restricting access to these ports reduces the attack surface and enforces data handling policies.
plain_english_explanation: This control requires organizations to physically or logically disable unused ports and I/O devices on computer systems. USB ports, optical drives, and other peripheral interfaces can be exploited to steal data or introduce malicious software. By disabling or removing unnecessary ports on sensitive systems, you eliminate these attack vectors and ensure only authorized devices can connect to the system.
ai_guidance: When implementing SC-41 Port and I/O Device Access controls, organizations must take a systematic approach to identifying and restricting physical ports and I/O devices. Begin by conducting a comprehensive inventory of all ports available on each system, including USB (all types), FireWire, Thunderbolt, eSATA, SD card slots, optical drives, and legacy parallel/serial ports. For each system category, determine which ports are operationally necessary and create an approved device whitelist. Linux systems can leverage udev rules to enforce USB device restrictions based on vendor ID, product ID, or device class. The USBGuard daemon provides enterprise-grade USB device authorization policy enforcement. Windows environments should use Group Policy to disable USB storage devices while allowing keyboards and mice. Consider BIOS/UEFI-level port disabling for maximum security on high-sensitivity systems. Document all exceptions with business justification and implement compensating controls such as endpoint DLP for approved removable media. Regularly audit port configurations and connected device logs to detect policy violations or unauthorized access attempts.
example_implementation: Implement strict access controls by disabling unnecessary ports at the BIOS/UEFI level and using operating system controls to restrict which device types can connect to remaining enabled ports.
non_technical_guidance:
1. Inventory all physical ports on organizational systems.
2. Identify which ports are required for business operations.
3. Develop a policy specifying which ports should be disabled or removed.
4. For software-based controls, configure operating systems to block unauthorized device types.
5. For hardware-based controls, disable ports in BIOS/UEFI or physically remove/block ports.
6. Document all authorized exceptions with business justification.
7. Regularly audit port configurations and connected device activity.

linux.bash:
#!/bin/bash
# SC-41: Port and I/O Device Access - USB Mass Storage Restriction
# This script disables USB mass storage to prevent data exfiltration

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-41] Implementing port and I/O device access controls..."

# Method 1: Blacklist USB storage kernel module
echo "Blacklisting USB mass storage module..."
cat > /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage-blacklist.conf << 'EOF'
# SC-41: Disable USB mass storage devices
install usb-storage /bin/false
blacklist usb-storage
EOF

# Method 2: Create udev rule to block USB storage devices
echo "Creating udev rules for USB device restrictions..."
cat > /etc/udev/rules.d/99-usb-storage-block.conf << 'EOF'
# SC-41: Block USB storage device class (08 = mass storage)
ACTION=="add", SUBSYSTEMS=="usb", ATTR{bInterfaceClass}=="08", RUN+="/bin/sh -c 'echo 0 > /sys$DEVPATH/../authorized'"
EOF

# Reload udev rules
udevadm control --reload-rules
udevadm trigger

# Unload module if currently loaded
if lsmod | grep -q usb_storage; then
    echo "Unloading usb-storage module..."
    modprobe -r usb_storage 2>/dev/null || echo "Warning: Could not unload usb_storage - devices may be in use"
fi

# Rebuild initramfs to ensure persistence
if command -v dracut &>/dev/null; then
    dracut -f
elif command -v update-initramfs &>/dev/null; then
    update-initramfs -u
fi

echo "[SC-41] USB mass storage restrictions implemented successfully"
echo "Note: Reboot recommended to fully apply changes"
linux.ansible:
---
# SC-41: Port and I/O Device Access - Ansible Playbook
- name: SC-41 - Implement Port and I/O Device Access Controls
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    blocked_modules:
      - usb-storage
      - firewire-core
      - thunderbolt

  tasks:
    - name: Create modprobe blacklist for USB storage
      copy:
        dest: /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage-blacklist.conf
        content: |
          # SC-41: Disable USB mass storage devices
          install usb-storage /bin/false
          blacklist usb-storage
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0644'
      notify: Rebuild initramfs

    - name: Create udev rule to block USB storage class
      copy:
        dest: /etc/udev/rules.d/99-usb-storage-block.conf
        content: |
          # SC-41: Block USB storage device class
          ACTION=="add", SUBSYSTEMS=="usb", ATTR{bInterfaceClass}=="08", RUN+="/bin/sh -c 'echo 0 > /sys$DEVPATH/../authorized'"
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0644'
      notify: Reload udev rules

    - name: Unload USB storage module if loaded
      modprobe:
        name: usb_storage
        state: absent
      ignore_errors: yes

  handlers:
    - name: Reload udev rules
      command: udevadm control --reload-rules

    - name: Rebuild initramfs
      command: dracut -f
      when: ansible_os_family == 'RedHat'

windows.powershell:
# SC-41: Port and I/O Device Access - Windows USB Restriction
# This script disables USB mass storage devices via registry and Group Policy

#Requires -RunAsAdministrator

Write-Host "[SC-41] Implementing port and I/O device access controls..." -ForegroundColor Cyan

# Method 1: Disable USB Storage Driver via Registry
$usbStorPath = "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\USBSTOR"
if (Test-Path $usbStorPath) {
    Set-ItemProperty -Path $usbStorPath -Name "Start" -Value 4 -Type DWord
    Write-Host "USB Storage driver disabled via registry" -ForegroundColor Green
} else {
    Write-Host "Warning: USBSTOR registry path not found" -ForegroundColor Yellow
}

# Method 2: Block removable storage via Group Policy registry keys
$removableStoragePath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\RemovableStorageDevices"
if (-not (Test-Path $removableStoragePath)) {
    New-Item -Path $removableStoragePath -Force | Out-Null
}

# Block USB removable disks
$usbDiskPath = "$removableStoragePath\{53f5630d-b6bf-11d0-94f2-00a0c91efb8b}"
if (-not (Test-Path $usbDiskPath)) {
    New-Item -Path $usbDiskPath -Force | Out-Null
}
Set-ItemProperty -Path $usbDiskPath -Name "Deny_All" -Value 1 -Type DWord
Write-Host "USB removable disk access denied via policy" -ForegroundColor Green

# Block CD/DVD drives
$cdromPath = "$removableStoragePath\{53f56308-b6bf-11d0-94f2-00a0c91efb8b}"
if (-not (Test-Path $cdromPath)) {
    New-Item -Path $cdromPath -Force | Out-Null
}
Set-ItemProperty -Path $cdromPath -Name "Deny_All" -Value 1 -Type DWord
Write-Host "CD/DVD drive access denied via policy" -ForegroundColor Green

# Verify settings
Write-Host "`n[SC-41] Verification:" -ForegroundColor Cyan
Get-ItemProperty -Path $usbStorPath -Name Start -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Select-Object Start

Write-Host "`n[SC-41] Port and I/O device restrictions implemented successfully" -ForegroundColor Green
Write-Host "Note: Restart may be required for full effect"

---
# SC-41: Port and I/O Device Access - Windows Ansible Playbook
- name: SC-41 - Implement Port and I/O Device Access Controls (Windows)
  hosts: windows
  gather_facts: yes

  tasks:
    - name: Disable USB Storage driver
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\USBSTOR
        name: Start
        data: 4
        type: dword

    - name: Create RemovableStorageDevices policy key
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\RemovableStorageDevices
        state: present

    - name: Block USB removable disks
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\RemovableStorageDevices\{53f5630d-b6bf-11d0-94f2-00a0c91efb8b}
        name: Deny_All
        data: 1
        type: dword

    - name: Block CD/DVD drives
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\RemovableStorageDevices\{53f56308-b6bf-11d0-94f2-00a0c91efb8b}
        name: Deny_All
        data: 1

intent: To prevent unauthorized collection of sensitive information through sensors embedded in devices such as cameras, microphones, and GPS receivers by establishing controls over sensor-enabled devices in sensitive areas.
rationale: Modern devices contain numerous sensors capable of capturing audio, video, location data, and environmental information. In sensitive facilities or during classified discussions, these sensors pose significant security risks including eavesdropping, visual espionage, and location tracking. Controlling sensor capabilities protects confidential communications and sensitive activities.
plain_english_explanation: This control requires organizations to manage devices with sensors (cameras, microphones, GPS, accelerometers) in sensitive areas. You must identify where sensor-enabled devices pose risks, determine which users may bring such devices into those areas, and establish procedures for authorizing device use. This prevents unauthorized recording or tracking of sensitive activities and protects privacy.
ai_guidance: Implementing SC-42 Sensor Capability and Data controls requires a multi-layered approach addressing both policy and technical measures. First, conduct a comprehensive survey to identify all organizational areas where sensor-enabled devices could capture sensitive information (conference rooms, SCIFs, data centers, executive offices). Create a classification system for these areas based on sensitivity levels. For each classification, define which sensor types are prohibited (cameras, microphones, GPS, accelerometers, ambient light sensors). Develop procedures for device authorization that include security checks, sensor disabling verification, and accountability logs. Technical implementations may include mobile device management (MDM) solutions that can enforce camera/microphone disabling, RF shielding for highly sensitive areas, signal detection equipment to identify unauthorized transmissions, and physical device storage facilities outside restricted zones. For software-based sensors in enterprise applications, implement application-level permissions controls and audit logging for sensor access. Regularly audit sensor access logs, conduct periodic sweeps for unauthorized devices, and train personnel on sensor risks and device handling procedures. Consider implementing automated sensor detection systems for high-security environments.
example_implementation: Deploy mobile device management to control sensor access, establish device check-in procedures for sensitive areas, and implement technical detection capabilities for unauthorized sensor-equipped devices.
non_technical_guidance:
1. Identify all facilities and areas where sensor-enabled devices pose security risks.
2. Classify areas by sensitivity level and define sensor restrictions for each level.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-42: Sensor Capability and Data - Audit sensor device access
# This script audits and optionally disables sensor devices on Linux systems

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-42] Auditing sensor devices and capabilities..."

# Audit audio input devices (microphones)
echo -e "\n=== Audio Input Devices ==="
if command -v arecord &>/dev/null; then
    arecord -l 2>/dev/null || echo "No audio capture devices found"
else
    echo "ALSA tools not installed - checking /dev directly"
    ls -la /dev/snd/pcm*c* 2>/dev/null || echo "No capture devices in /dev/snd"
fi

# Audit video capture devices (cameras)
echo -e "\n=== Video Capture Devices ==="
if [ -d /dev ]; then
    ls -la /dev/video* 2>/dev/null || echo "No video devices found"
fi

# Check for webcam modules loaded
echo -e "\n=== Webcam Kernel Modules ==="
lsmod | grep -E 'uvcvideo|v4l2|videobuf' || echo "No video modules loaded"

# Check for sensor-related modules (accelerometer, GPS, etc.)
echo -e "\n=== Sensor Kernel Modules ==="
lsmod | grep -E 'iio|sensor|accelerometer|gyro|magnetometer' || echo "No sensor modules loaded"

# Generate report
echo -e "\n=== SC-42 Sensor Audit Report ==="
cat << 'REPORT'
Review the above output and ensure:
1. Only authorized sensor devices are present
2. Unnecessary sensor modules are blacklisted
3. User access to sensor devices is restricted via udev rules
4. Sensor access is logged for security monitoring
REPORT

# Optional: Disable camera module (uncomment to enable)
# echo "Disabling webcam module..."
# echo "blacklist uvcvideo" > /etc/modprobe.d/disable-webcam.conf
# modprobe -r uvcvideo 2>/dev/null || true

echo "\n[SC-42] Sensor audit complete"

# SC-42: Sensor Capability and Data - Ansible Playbook
- name: SC-42 - Manage Sensor Capabilities
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    disable_webcam: false
    disable_microphone: false
    audit_only: true

  tasks:
    - name: Gather sensor device information
      shell: |
        echo "=== Video Devices ==="
        ls -la /dev/video* 2>/dev/null || echo "None"
        echo "=== Audio Capture ==="
        ls -la /dev/snd/pcm*c* 2>/dev/null || echo "None"
        echo "=== Sensor Modules ==="
        lsmod | grep -E 'uvcvideo|v4l2|iio|sensor' || echo "None"
      register: sensor_audit
      changed_when: false

    - name: Display sensor audit results
      debug:
        var: sensor_audit.stdout_lines

    - name: Blacklist webcam module (if requested)
      copy:
        dest: /etc/modprobe.d/disable-webcam.conf
        content: |
          # SC-42: Disable webcam access
          blacklist uvcvideo
          install uvcvideo /bin/false
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0644'
      when: disable_webcam | bool
      notify: Unload webcam module

    - name: Create udev rule for sensor device logging
      copy:
        dest: /etc/udev/rules.d/99-sensor-audit.rules
        content: |
          # SC-42: Log sensor device access
          SUBSYSTEM=="video4linux", RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -t SC42-AUDIT 'Video device accessed: %k'"
          SUBSYSTEM=="sound", ATTR{id}=="*Capture*", RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -t SC42-AUDIT 'Audio capture device accessed: %k'"
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0644'
      notify: Reload udev

  handlers:
    - name: Unload webcam module
      modprobe:
        name: uvcvideo
        state: absent
      ignore_errors: yes

    - name: Reload udev
      command: udevadm control --reload-rules

intent: To ensure that high-risk system components with potential security implications are used only under controlled conditions with appropriate restrictions, authorization, and monitoring.
rationale: Certain system components such as remote access tools, encryption software, virtualization platforms, and development environments can be exploited if misused. By establishing clear usage restrictions, requiring explicit authorization, and implementing monitoring, organizations reduce the risk of these powerful tools being weaponized against the organization.
plain_english_explanation: This control requires organizations to identify system components that could pose security risks if misused, establish rules for how they can be used, and monitor their usage. Examples include remote desktop software, packet capture tools, debugging utilities, and privileged administrative tools. By controlling and monitoring these components, you prevent unauthorized or malicious use while still enabling legitimate business functions.
ai_guidance: Implementing SC-43 Usage Restrictions requires organizations to take a risk-based approach to identifying and controlling potentially dangerous system components. Begin by cataloging all system components that could pose elevated security risks, including remote access tools (RDP, SSH, VNC), network analysis utilities (Wireshark, tcpdump, nmap), system debugging tools (debuggers, decompilers), encryption/decryption tools, virtualization and container platforms, development and build tools, and privileged administrative utilities. For each identified component, develop specific usage guidelines addressing who may use the component (role-based authorization), under what circumstances use is permitted, what data may be accessed or processed, logging and monitoring requirements, and periodic access review schedules. Implement technical controls including application whitelisting to prevent unauthorized tool installation, privileged access management (PAM) solutions for tool authorization, comprehensive audit logging of tool usage, just-in-time access provisioning for sensitive tools, and network segmentation to limit tool reach. Establish monitoring dashboards to detect anomalous tool usage patterns that may indicate compromise or misuse. Conduct regular reviews of component usage logs and authorization lists.

1. Inventory all system components with potential security implications.
2. Categorize components by risk level and required authorization level.
3. Develop written usage guidelines for each component category.
4. Establish an authorization process requiring management approval for high-risk tools.
5. Implement logging and monitoring for all controlled components.
6. Conduct quarterly reviews of authorizations and usage logs.
7. Train personnel on acceptable use policies for controlled components.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-43: Usage Restrictions - Control and Monitor High-Risk Tools
# This script implements usage restrictions for sensitive system components

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-43] Implementing usage restrictions for system components..."

# Define restricted tools and their allowed groups
declare -A RESTRICTED_TOOLS=(
    ["/usr/bin/tcpdump"]="network-admins"
    ["/usr/sbin/tcpdump"]="network-admins"
    ["/usr/bin/nmap"]="security-team"
    ["/usr/bin/wireshark"]="security-team"
    ["/usr/bin/strace"]="developers"
    ["/usr/bin/gdb"]="developers"
)

# Configure audit rules for restricted tools
echo "Configuring audit logging for restricted tools..."
cat > /etc/audit/rules.d/sc-43-usage-restrictions.rules << 'EOF'
# SC-43: Audit usage of restricted tools
-w /usr/bin/tcpdump -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/sbin/tcpdump -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/bin/nmap -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/bin/wireshark -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/bin/strace -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/bin/gdb -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
-w /usr/bin/ssh -p x -k remote_access_usage
-w /usr/bin/scp -p x -k remote_access_usage
EOF

# Reload audit rules
augenrules --load 2>/dev/null || auditctl -R /etc/audit/rules.d/sc-43-usage-restrictions.rules

# Set restrictive permissions on sensitive tools
echo "Setting restrictive permissions on sensitive tools..."
for tool in "${!RESTRICTED_TOOLS[@]}"; do
    if [ -f "$tool" ]; then
        group="${RESTRICTED_TOOLS[$tool]}"
        # Create group if it doesn't exist
        getent group "$group" >/dev/null || groupadd "$group"
        # Set ownership and permissions
        chown root:"$group" "$tool"
        chmod 750 "$tool"
        echo "Restricted: $tool -> group:$group"
    fi
done

# Configure sudo for controlled access
echo "Configuring sudo for authorized tool usage..."
cat > /etc/sudoers.d/sc-43-restricted-tools << 'EOF'
# SC-43: Controlled access to restricted tools
%network-admins ALL=(root) /usr/bin/tcpdump, /usr/sbin/tcpdump
%security-team ALL=(root) /usr/bin/nmap, /usr/bin/wireshark
%developers ALL=(root) /usr/bin/strace, /usr/bin/gdb
EOF
chmod 440 /etc/sudoers.d/sc-43-restricted-tools

echo "[SC-43] Usage restrictions implemented successfully"
echo "Note: Ensure users are added to appropriate groups for authorized access"
linux.ansible:
---
# SC-43: Usage Restrictions - Ansible Playbook
- name: SC-43 - Implement Usage Restrictions
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    restricted_tools:
      - path: /usr/bin/tcpdump
        group: network-admins
      - path: /usr/bin/nmap
        group: security-team
      - path: /usr/bin/wireshark
        group: security-team
      - path: /usr/bin/strace
        group: developers
      - path: /usr/bin/gdb
        group: developers

  tasks:
    - name: Create authorization groups
      group:
        name: "{{ item.group }}"
        state: present
      loop: "{{ restricted_tools }}"
      loop_control:
        label: "{{ item.group }}"

    - name: Set restrictive permissions on tools
      file:
        path: "{{ item.path }}"
        owner: root
        group: "{{ item.group }}"
        mode: '0750'
      loop: "{{ restricted_tools }}"
      when: item.path is exists
      loop_control:
        label: "{{ item.path }}"

    - name: Configure audit rules for restricted tools
      copy:
        dest: /etc/audit/rules.d/sc-43-usage-restrictions.rules
        content: |
          # SC-43: Audit usage of restricted tools
          -w /usr/bin/tcpdump -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
          -w /usr/bin/nmap -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
          -w /usr/bin/wireshark -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
          -w /usr/bin/strace -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
          -w /usr/bin/gdb -p x -k restricted_tool_usage
          -w /usr/bin/ssh -p x -k remote_access_usage
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0640'
      notify: Reload audit rules

    - name: Configure sudo for authorized tool access
      copy:
        dest: /etc/sudoers.d/sc-43-restricted-tools
        content: |
          # SC-43: Controlled access to restricted tools
          %network-admins ALL=(root) /usr/bin/tcpdump
          %security-team ALL=(root) /usr/bin/nmap, /usr/bin/wireshark

# SC-43: Usage Restrictions - Windows Tool Control
# This script implements usage restrictions for sensitive Windows components

#Requires -RunAsAdministrator

Write-Host "[SC-43] Implementing usage restrictions for system components..." -ForegroundColor Cyan

# Define restricted applications for AppLocker or WDAC
$restrictedApps = @(
    @{Name="PowerShell ISE"; Path="%SystemRoot%\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell_ise.exe"; Group="Developers"},
    @{Name="Remote Desktop"; Path="%SystemRoot%\System32\mstsc.exe"; Group="Remote-Access-Users"},
    @{Name="Registry Editor"; Path="%SystemRoot%\regedit.exe"; Group="System-Admins"},
    @{Name="Command Prompt"; Path="%SystemRoot%\System32\cmd.exe"; Group="Authorized-Users"}
)

# Enable command-line auditing
Write-Host "Enabling command-line process auditing..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
$auditPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\Audit"
if (-not (Test-Path $auditPath)) {
    New-Item -Path $auditPath -Force | Out-Null
}
Set-ItemProperty -Path $auditPath -Name "ProcessCreationIncludeCmdLine_Enabled" -Value 1 -Type DWord

# Configure advanced audit policy for process tracking
Write-Host "Configuring process tracking audit policy..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
auditpol /set /subcategory:"Process Creation" /success:enable /failure:enable
auditpol /set /subcategory:"Process Termination" /success:enable

# Enable PowerShell script block logging
Write-Host "Enabling PowerShell script block logging..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
$psLogPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\ScriptBlockLogging"
if (-not (Test-Path $psLogPath)) {
    New-Item -Path $psLogPath -Force | Out-Null
}
Set-ItemProperty -Path $psLogPath -Name "EnableScriptBlockLogging" -Value 1 -Type DWord

# Enable PowerShell module logging
$psModLogPath = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\ModuleLogging"
if (-not (Test-Path $psModLogPath)) {
    New-Item -Path $psModLogPath -Force | Out-Null
}
Set-ItemProperty -Path $psModLogPath -Name "EnableModuleLogging" -Value 1 -Type DWord

# Create local security groups for tool authorization
Write-Host "Creating authorization groups..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
$groups = @("Developers", "Remote-Access-Users", "System-Admins", "Security-Team")
foreach ($group in $groups) {
    $existingGroup = Get-LocalGroup -Name $group -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
    if (-not $existingGroup) {
        New-LocalGroup -Name $group -Description "SC-43 Authorized users for restricted tools"
        Write-Host "Created group: $group" -ForegroundColor Green
    }
}

# Display AppLocker configuration guidance
Write-Host "`n=== AppLocker Configuration Guidance ===" -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "To enforce executable restrictions, configure AppLocker policies via:"
Write-Host "1. Local Security Policy -> Application Control Policies -> AppLocker"
Write-Host "2. Create rules allowing only specified groups to run restricted executables"
Write-Host "3. Set enforcement mode to 'Enforce rules'"

Write-Host "`n[SC-43] Usage restrictions configured successfully" -ForegroundColor Green

  hosts: windows
  gather_facts: yes

  tasks:
    - name: Enable command-line process auditing

        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\Audit
        name: ProcessCreationIncludeCmdLine_Enabled
        data: 1
        type: dword

    - name: Configure process creation auditing
      win_shell: |
        auditpol /set /subcategory:"Process Creation" /success:enable /failure:enable

    - name: Enable PowerShell script block logging
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\ScriptBlockLogging
        name: EnableScriptBlockLogging
        data: 1
        type: dword

    - name: Enable PowerShell module logging
      win_regedit:
        path: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\ModuleLogging
        name: EnableModuleLogging
        data: 1
        type: dword

    - name: Create authorization groups
      win_group:
        name: "{{ item }}"
        description: "SC-43 Authorized users for restricted tools"
        state: present
      loop:
        - Developers
        - Remote-Access-Users
        - System-Admins
        - Security-Team

intent: To safely analyze suspicious code, files, and URLs in an isolated environment that prevents potential malware from affecting production systems while enabling security teams to understand threat behavior.
rationale: Modern malware often evades signature-based detection and requires behavioral analysis to identify. Detonation chambers (sandboxes) provide isolated environments where suspicious content can be executed and observed without risk to operational systems. This enables proactive threat detection, incident response, and security research.
plain_english_explanation: This control requires organizations to maintain sandboxing or detonation capabilities for safely executing and analyzing suspicious files, code, or URLs. A detonation chamber is an isolated virtual environment that mimics a real system where malware can run without causing actual damage. Security analysts can observe the malware's behavior, identify indicators of compromise, and develop detection signatures. This is critical for analyzing targeted attacks, zero-day threats, and suspicious email attachments.
ai_guidance: Implementing SC-44 Detonation Chambers requires establishing isolated analysis environments for suspicious content. Organizations can choose between commercial sandbox solutions (FireEye, Palo Alto WildFire, Cisco Threat Grid, Joe Sandbox) or open-source options (Cuckoo Sandbox, CAPE Sandbox, Any.Run). Key implementation considerations include network isolation ensuring the sandbox cannot reach production systems except through controlled channels, realistic environment configuration with common software (Office, Adobe, browsers) to trigger malware behaviors, anti-evasion measures as sophisticated malware detects virtualization and alters behavior, automated submission pipelines integrating email gateways and web proxies to automatically submit suspicious content, comprehensive logging capturing network traffic, file system changes, registry modifications, process activity, and API calls, indicator extraction automatically extracting IOCs (hashes, domains, IPs, mutex names) for threat intelligence, and retention policies for preserving analysis artifacts for incident response and threat hunting. For infrastructure, consider dedicated analysis networks with appropriate air-gapping, VLAN segmentation, or software-defined isolation. Implement snapshot/rollback capabilities for rapid environment restoration. Establish procedures for human analyst review of automated sandbox results, especially for targeted threats that may require extended analysis or manual investigation.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-44: Detonation Chambers - Cuckoo Sandbox Deployment
# This script prepares the environment for Cuckoo Sandbox installation

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-44] Preparing detonation chamber environment..."

# Check if running on appropriate system
if [ "$(id -u)" -ne 0 ]; then
    echo "Error: This script must be run as root"
    exit 1
fi

# Install dependencies for Cuckoo Sandbox
echo "Installing base dependencies..."
apt-get update
apt-get install -y python3 python3-pip python3-dev python3-venv \
    libffi-dev libssl-dev libjpeg-dev zlib1g-dev \
    swig mongodb postgresql libpq-dev \
    virtualbox virtualbox-dkms virtualbox-ext-pack \
    tcpdump libcap2-bin apparmor-utils \
    volatility yara ssdeep libfuzzy-dev

# Create dedicated cuckoo user
echo "Creating cuckoo service account..."
if ! id "cuckoo" &>/dev/null; then
    useradd -m -s /bin/bash cuckoo
    usermod -aG vboxusers cuckoo
fi

# Configure tcpdump for non-root capture
echo "Configuring tcpdump for cuckoo user..."
setcap cap_net_raw,cap_net_admin=eip /usr/sbin/tcpdump
aa-disable /usr/sbin/tcpdump 2>/dev/null || true

# Create isolated network for sandbox VMs
echo "Creating isolated analysis network..."
vboxmanage hostonlyif create 2>/dev/null || true
vboxmanage hostonlyif ipconfig vboxnet0 --ip 192.168.56.1 --netmask 255.255.255.0

# Configure iptables for network isolation
echo "Configuring network isolation rules..."
iptables -A FORWARD -o vboxnet0 -m state --state RELATED,ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
iptables -A FORWARD -i vboxnet0 -o eth0 -j DROP  # Block direct internet access
iptables -A FORWARD -i vboxnet0 -d 192.168.56.0/24 -j ACCEPT

# Create directory structure
echo "Creating Cuckoo directory structure..."
mkdir -p /opt/cuckoo/{storage,log}
chown -R cuckoo:cuckoo /opt/cuckoo

echo ""
echo "[SC-44] Detonation chamber environment prepared"
echo "Next steps:"
echo "1. Create Windows analysis VMs in VirtualBox"
echo "2. Install Cuckoo agent in analysis VMs"
echo "3. Configure Cuckoo with appropriate analysis settings"
echo "4. Integrate with email/web security gateways"
echo ""
echo "Documentation: https://cuckoo.readthedocs.io/"

official_text: Synchronize system clocks within and between systems and system components.
intent: To ensure accurate and consistent timekeeping across all systems and components, enabling reliable audit log correlation, cryptographic operations, and time-sensitive security controls.
rationale: Accurate time synchronization is foundational to security operations. Audit logs from multiple systems can only be correlated if timestamps are consistent. Kerberos authentication, TLS certificate validation, and many cryptographic protocols depend on accurate time. Without synchronized time, incident response becomes extremely difficult and security controls may fail.
plain_english_explanation: This control requires all systems to synchronize their clocks with a reliable time source. When investigating security incidents, you need to correlate events across multiple systems - this is impossible if system clocks differ significantly. Many security protocols (Kerberos, certificates) also depend on accurate time. Configure NTP or similar protocols to keep all systems synchronized to within acceptable tolerances.
ai_guidance: Implementing SC-45 System Time Synchronization requires configuring reliable NTP infrastructure across the enterprise. For authoritative time sources, prefer GPS-synchronized stratum 1 servers or connect to NIST (time.nist.gov) or authenticated NTP pools. Linux systems should use chronyd (preferred on RHEL/CentOS 8+) or ntpd, configured with multiple upstream servers for redundancy. Key configuration includes setting appropriate polling intervals (typically 64-1024 seconds), enabling iburst for fast initial synchronization, configuring maxpoll and minpoll appropriately for your network, implementing authentication using NTP symmetric keys or NTS (Network Time Security) for chrony, and restricting NTP server access to prevent amplification attacks. Windows systems should configure the Windows Time Service (W32Time) to use domain controllers as time sources (domain members) or external NTP servers (standalone systems). For domain controllers, the PDC emulator should sync with an external authoritative source. Monitor time offset and ensure all systems maintain offset within acceptable tolerances (typically less than 1 second for general use, sub-millisecond for high-frequency trading or precise audit correlation). Implement alerting when systems drift beyond acceptable thresholds. Document approved time sources and synchronization topology.
example_implementation: Configure chronyd or ntpd to synchronize with multiple stratum 1/2 time sources, implement NTP authentication to prevent time-based attacks, and monitor time offset across all systems.
non_technical_guidance:
1. Identify authoritative time sources for the organization (GPS, NIST, authenticated NTP pools).
2. Design time synchronization hierarchy (stratum levels).
3. Configure all systems to synchronize with approved time sources.
4. Implement monitoring for time drift beyond acceptable thresholds.
5. Document approved time sources and synchronization architecture.
6. Test time synchronization regularly as part of security monitoring.
7. Ensure redundant time sources to prevent single points of failure.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-45: System Time Synchronization - chronyd Configuration
# This script configures chronyd for secure time synchronization

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-45] Configuring system time synchronization..."

# Verify chronyd is installed
if ! command -v chronyd &>/dev/null; then
    echo "Installing chrony..."
    if command -v dnf &>/dev/null; then
        dnf install -y chrony
    elif command -v apt-get &>/dev/null; then
        apt-get update && apt-get install -y chrony
    else
        echo "Error: Unable to install chrony - unknown package manager"
        exit 1
    fi
fi

# Backup existing configuration
cp /etc/chrony.conf /etc/chrony.conf.bak.$(date +%Y%m%d)

# Configure chrony with multiple authoritative sources
echo "Configuring chrony with authoritative time sources..."
cat > /etc/chrony.conf << 'EOF'
# SC-45: System Time Synchronization Configuration
# Generated by security hardening script

# NIST authoritative time sources (stratum 1)
server time.nist.gov iburst prefer
server time-a-g.nist.gov iburst
server time-b-g.nist.gov iburst
server time-c-g.nist.gov iburst

# Backup pool servers
pool pool.ntp.org iburst maxsources 4

# Record the rate at which the system clock gains/loses time
driftfile /var/lib/chrony/drift

# Allow system clock to be stepped in first three updates if offset > 1 second
makestep 1.0 3

# Enable kernel synchronization of the real-time clock (RTC)
rtcsync

# Specify directory for log files
logdir /var/log/chrony

# Log measurements, statistics, tracking, and RTC adjustments
log measurements statistics tracking rtc

# Restrict access - only allow localhost to configure
allow 127.0.0.1
allow ::1

# Deny all other access by default
deny all

# Set minimum stratum to prevent serving time if not synchronized
local stratum 10

# Specify the NTP key file for authentication
keyfile /etc/chrony.keys

# Set maximum offset for logging (100ms)
logchange 0.1
EOF

# Enable and start chronyd
echo "Enabling and starting chronyd service..."
systemctl enable chronyd
systemctl restart chronyd

# Wait for initial sync
echo "Waiting for time synchronization..."
sleep 5

# Verify synchronization status
echo -e "\n=== Chrony Synchronization Status ==="
chronyc tracking

echo -e "\n=== Chrony Sources ==="
chronyc sources -v

# Check time offset
OFFSET=$(chronyc tracking | grep 'System time' | awk '{print $4}')
echo -e "\nCurrent system time offset: $OFFSET seconds"

# Configure firewall for NTP if firewalld is active
if systemctl is-active --quiet firewalld; then
    echo "Configuring firewall for NTP..."
    firewall-cmd --permanent --add-service=ntp
    firewall-cmd --reload
fi

echo "\n[SC-45] Time synchronization configured successfully"

---
# SC-45: System Time Synchronization - Ansible Playbook
- name: SC-45 - Configure System Time Synchronization
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    ntp_servers:
      - time.nist.gov
      - time-a-g.nist.gov
      - time-b-g.nist.gov
    ntp_pool: pool.ntp.org
    max_offset_seconds: 1.0
    max_step_count: 3

  tasks:
    - name: Install chrony
      package:
        name: chrony
        state: present

    - name: Backup existing chrony configuration
      copy:
        src: /etc/chrony.conf
        dest: /etc/chrony.conf.backup
        remote_src: yes
        force: no
      ignore_errors: yes

    - name: Configure chrony with authoritative time sources
      template:
        dest: /etc/chrony.conf
        content: |
          # SC-45: System Time Synchronization
          # Managed by Ansible
          
          {% for server in ntp_servers %}
          server {{ server }} iburst{% if loop.first %} prefer{% endif %}
          
          {% endfor %}
          pool {{ ntp_pool }} iburst maxsources 4
          
          driftfile /var/lib/chrony/drift
          makestep {{ max_offset_seconds }} {{ max_step_count }}
          rtcsync
          logdir /var/log/chrony
          log measurements statistics tracking
          
          allow 127.0.0.1
          allow ::1
          deny all
          
          local stratum 10
          logchange 0.1
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: '0644'
      notify: Restart chronyd

    - name: Enable and start chronyd
      systemd:
        name: chronyd
        state: started
        enabled: yes

    - name: Verify time synchronization
      command: chronyc tracking
      register: chrony_status
      changed_when: false

    - name: Display synchronization status
      debug:
        var: chrony_status.stdout_lines

    - name: Configure firewall for NTP (if firewalld)
      firewalld:
        service: ntp
        permanent: yes
        state: enabled
      when: ansible_facts.services['firewalld.service'] is defined
      notify: Reload firewalld

  handlers:
    - name: Restart chronyd
      systemd:
        name: chronyd
        state: restarted

    - name: Reload firewalld
      command: firewall-cmd --reload

# SC-45: System Time Synchronization - Windows Time Service Configuration
# This script configures W32Time for secure time synchronization

#Requires -RunAsAdministrator

Write-Host "[SC-45] Configuring Windows Time Service..." -ForegroundColor Cyan

# Define authoritative NTP servers
$ntpServers = "time.nist.gov,0x9 time-a-g.nist.gov,0x9 time-b-g.nist.gov,0x9"

# Stop the time service
Write-Host "Stopping Windows Time service..."
Stop-Service w32time -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Configure time service type
Write-Host "Configuring NTP client settings..."
w32tm /config /manualpeerlist:$ntpServers /syncfromflags:manual /reliable:yes /update

# Set registry values for enhanced configuration
$w32timePath = "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\W32Time"

# Enable NTP client
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\TimeProviders\NtpClient" -Name "Enabled" -Value 1 -Type DWord

# Set poll interval (in seconds) - 3600 = 1 hour
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\Config" -Name "MaxPollInterval" -Value 15 -Type DWord  # 2^15 seconds = ~9 hours max
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\Config" -Name "MinPollInterval" -Value 10 -Type DWord  # 2^10 seconds = ~17 minutes min

# Configure correction thresholds
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\Config" -Name "MaxNegPhaseCorrection" -Value 54000 -Type DWord  # 15 hours
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\Config" -Name "MaxPosPhaseCorrection" -Value 54000 -Type DWord  # 15 hours

# Enable event logging for time service
Set-ItemProperty -Path "$w32timePath\Config" -Name "EventLogFlags" -Value 3 -Type DWord

# Start and configure automatic startup
Write-Host "Starting Windows Time service..."
Set-Service -Name w32time -StartupType Automatic
Start-Service w32time

# Force immediate sync
Write-Host "Forcing immediate time synchronization..."
w32tm /resync /force

# Wait for sync to complete
Start-Sleep -Seconds 5

# Verify configuration
Write-Host "`n=== Windows Time Configuration ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /configuration

Write-Host "`n=== Time Source Status ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /status /verbose

Write-Host "`n=== Configured Peers ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /peers

# Check current offset
$status = w32tm /query /status
$offsetLine = $status | Select-String "Phase Offset"
if ($offsetLine) {
    Write-Host "`nCurrent time offset: $($offsetLine.ToString().Trim())"
}

# Configure Windows Firewall for NTP (outbound)
Write-Host "`nConfiguring firewall for NTP..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
$ntpRule = Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "NTP Outbound" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
if (-not $ntpRule) {
    New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "NTP Outbound" -Direction Outbound -Protocol UDP -RemotePort 123 -Action Allow -Profile Any
    Write-Host "NTP outbound firewall rule created" -ForegroundColor Green
}

Write-Host "`n[SC-45] Windows Time synchronization configured successfully" -ForegroundColor Green

#!/bin/bash
# SC-45.1: Synchronization with Authoritative Time Source
# Configures chrony for authoritative time source comparison

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-45.1] Configuring authoritative time source synchronization..."

# Ensure chrony is installed and configured
if ! command -v chronyc &>/dev/null; then
    echo "Error: chrony is not installed. Run SC-45 implementation first."
    exit 1
fi

# Verify authoritative source configuration
echo "Checking authoritative time source configuration..."
if ! grep -q 'time.nist.gov' /etc/chrony.conf; then
    echo "Warning: NIST time server not configured. Adding..."
    echo "server time.nist.gov iburst prefer" >> /etc/chrony.conf
    systemctl restart chronyd
fi

# Check current synchronization status
echo -e "\n=== Current Synchronization Status ==="
chronyc tracking

# Get offset value
OFFSET_SEC=$(chronyc tracking | grep 'System time' | awk '{print $4}')
echo -e "\nCurrent offset: $OFFSET_SEC seconds"

# Check if offset exceeds threshold (1 second)
OFFSET_ABS=$(echo "$OFFSET_SEC" | tr -d '-')
if (( $(echo "$OFFSET_ABS > 1" | bc -l) )); then
    echo "WARNING: Time offset exceeds 1 second threshold!"
    echo "Forcing synchronization..."
    chronyc makestep
else
    echo "Time offset within acceptable threshold."
fi

# Verify sources are reachable
echo -e "\n=== Time Source Status ==="
chronyc sources -v

# Check synchronization frequency (polling interval)
echo -e "\n=== Polling Statistics ==="
chronyc sourcestats

# Log synchronization status for audit
logger -t SC-45.1 "Time sync check: offset=${OFFSET_SEC}s, sources=$(chronyc sources | grep -c '^\^')"

echo "\n[SC-45.1] Authoritative time source verification complete"

---
# SC-45.1: Synchronization with Authoritative Time Source - Ansible
- name: SC-45.1 - Verify Authoritative Time Source Synchronization
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    max_offset_threshold: 1.0  # seconds
    authoritative_sources:
      - time.nist.gov
      - time-a-g.nist.gov

  tasks:
    - name: Check chrony tracking status
      command: chronyc tracking
      register: chrony_tracking
      changed_when: false

    - name: Extract current offset
      set_fact:
        current_offset: "{{ chrony_tracking.stdout | regex_search('System time\\s+:\\s+([0-9.]+)', '\\1') | first | default('0') }}"

    - name: Display current offset
      debug:
        msg: "Current time offset: {{ current_offset }} seconds"

    - name: Force sync if offset exceeds threshold
      command: chronyc makestep
      when: current_offset | float > max_offset_threshold

    - name: Verify authoritative sources configured
      lineinfile:
        path: /etc/chrony.conf
        regexp: "^server {{ item }}"
        line: "server {{ item }} iburst"
        state: present
      loop: "{{ authoritative_sources }}"
      notify: Restart chronyd

    - name: Log sync status to syslog
      command: logger -t SC-45.1 "Time sync verified - offset={{ current_offset }}s"
      changed_when: false

  handlers:
    - name: Restart chronyd
      systemd:
        name: chronyd
        state: restarted

# SC-45.1: Synchronization with Authoritative Time Source - Windows
# Verifies and enforces synchronization with authoritative sources

#Requires -RunAsAdministrator

Write-Host "[SC-45.1] Verifying authoritative time source synchronization..." -ForegroundColor Cyan

# Define threshold (in seconds)
$offsetThreshold = 1.0

# Get current time status
$timeStatus = w32tm /query /status /verbose
Write-Host "`n=== Current Time Status ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
$timeStatus

# Extract phase offset
$offsetLine = $timeStatus | Select-String "Phase Offset"
if ($offsetLine) {
    $offsetMatch = [regex]::Match($offsetLine.ToString(), '([+-]?[0-9.]+)s')
    if ($offsetMatch.Success) {
        $currentOffset = [math]::Abs([double]$offsetMatch.Groups[1].Value)
        Write-Host "`nCurrent phase offset: $currentOffset seconds"
        
        if ($currentOffset -gt $offsetThreshold) {
            Write-Host "WARNING: Offset exceeds $offsetThreshold second threshold!" -ForegroundColor Red
            Write-Host "Forcing resynchronization..."
            w32tm /resync /force
            Start-Sleep -Seconds 5
            w32tm /query /status
        } else {
            Write-Host "Offset within acceptable threshold." -ForegroundColor Green
        }
    }
}

# Verify authoritative source configuration
Write-Host "`n=== Configured Time Sources ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /peers

# Log verification to event log
$logMessage = "SC-45.1: Time synchronization verified with authoritative source"
Write-EventLog -LogName Application -Source "W32Time" -EventId 1 -EntryType Information -Message $logMessage -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

Write-Host "`n[SC-45.1] Authoritative time source verification complete" -ForegroundColor Green

intent: To ensure time synchronization continues even if the primary time source becomes unavailable by maintaining a geographically diverse secondary source.
rationale: Single points of failure in time infrastructure can cascade into authentication failures, certificate validation errors, and audit log corruption. plain_english_explanation: This enhancement requires organizations to configure a backup time source located in a different geographic region from the primary source. For geographic diversity, if your primary source is in the Eastern US (e.g., time.nist.gov in Maryland), configure secondary sources in Western US (time-b-wwv.nist.gov in Colorado) or internationally. NTP client configuration handles failover automatically - chrony and ntpd query multiple servers and use the best available source. Configure at least 4 time sources for optimal operation (NTP algorithms work best with 4+ sources for Byzantine fault tolerance). Use the 'prefer' directive to designate the primary source while allowing automatic failover. Monitor time source availability and alert when sources become unreachable. Document primary and secondary time sources with their geographic locations. Consider diversity not just in geography but also in network paths (different ISPs, different DNS providers). For critical infrastructure, consider deploying local stratum 2 servers that sync with geographically diverse stratum 1 sources, providing local redundancy while maintaining authoritative accuracy.

#!/bin/bash
# SC-45.2: Secondary Authoritative Time Source
# Configures geographically diverse secondary time sources

set -euo pipefail

echo "[SC-45.2] Configuring geographically diverse time sources..."

# Define geographically diverse time sources
# Primary: NIST Gaithersburg, MD (Eastern US)
# Secondary: NIST Boulder, CO (Western US)
# Tertiary: International sources

cat > /etc/chrony.conf << 'EOF'
# SC-45.2: Geographically Diverse Time Sources
# Primary region: Eastern US (Gaithersburg, MD)
server time.nist.gov iburst prefer
server time-a-g.nist.gov iburst

# Secondary region: Western US (Boulder, CO)
server time-b-wwv.nist.gov iburst
server time-c-wwv.nist.gov iburst

# Tertiary: International/Pool (geographic diversity)
pool us.pool.ntp.org iburst maxsources 2
pool europe.pool.ntp.org iburst maxsources 2

# Clock drift tracking
driftfile /var/lib/chrony/drift

# Step clock if offset > 1 second during first 3 updates
makestep 1.0 3

# Sync RTC
rtcsync

# Logging
logdir /var/log/chrony
log measurements statistics tracking

# Access control
allow 127.0.0.1
allow ::1
deny all

# Local stratum when not synced
local stratum 10

# Log offset changes > 100ms
logchange 0.1
EOF

# Restart chrony to apply configuration
systemctl restart chronyd
sleep 5

# Verify geographic diversity
echo -e "\n=== Configured Time Sources (Geographic Diversity) ==="
chronyc sources -v

# Check source reachability
echo -e "\n=== Source Reachability ==="
for server in time.nist.gov time-b-wwv.nist.gov; do
    if chronyc sourcestats | grep -q "$server"; then
        echo "[OK] $server - reachable"
    else
        echo "[WARN] $server - checking ping..."
        ping -c 1 -W 5 "$server" &>/dev/null && echo "  -> Ping OK" || echo "  -> Unreachable"
    fi
done

# Test failover (informational)
echo -e "\n=== Failover Test Information ==="
echo "To test failover, temporarily block primary source:"
echo "  iptables -A OUTPUT -d time.nist.gov -j DROP"
echo "Then verify secondary takes over:"
echo "  chronyc sources"
echo "Remove block to restore:"
echo "  iptables -D OUTPUT -d time.nist.gov -j DROP"

echo "\n[SC-45.2] Geographic diversity configuration complete"

---
# SC-45.2: Secondary Authoritative Time Source - Ansible
- name: SC-45.2 - Configure Geographically Diverse Time Sources
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  vars:
    primary_sources:
      - server: time.nist.gov
        region: "Eastern US (Maryland)"
        prefer: true
      - server: time-a-g.nist.gov
        region: "Eastern US (Maryland)"
        prefer: false
    secondary_sources:
      - server: time-b-wwv.nist.gov
        region: "Western US (Colorado)"
      - server: time-c-wwv.nist.gov
        region: "Western US (Colorado)"
    pool_sources:
      - us.pool.ntp.org
      - europe.pool.ntp.org

  tasks:
    - name: Deploy chrony configuration with geographic diversity
      template:
        dest: /etc/chrony.conf
        content: |
          # SC-45.2: Geographically Diverse Time Sources
          # Managed by Ansible
          
          # Primary region (Eastern US)
          {% for source in primary_sources %}
          server {{ source.server }} iburst{% if source.prefer %} prefer{% endif %}

          {% endfor %}
          
          # Secondary region (Western US)
          {% for source in secondary_sources %}
          server {{ source.server }} iburst
          {% endfor %}
          
          # Pool sources for additional redundancy
          {% for pool in pool_sources %}
          pool {{ pool }} iburst maxsources 2
          {% endfor %}
          
          driftfile /var/lib/chrony/drift
          makestep 1.0 3
          rtcsync
          logdir /var/log/chrony
          log measurements statistics tracking

          deny all

          {% endfor %}

        owner: root
        mode: '0644'

    - name: Restart chronyd

        name: chronyd
        state: restarted

# SC-45.2: Secondary Authoritative Time Source - Windows
# Configures geographically diverse time sources for failover

#Requires -RunAsAdministrator

Write-Host "[SC-45.2] Configuring geographically diverse time sources..." -ForegroundColor Cyan

# Define geographically diverse NTP servers
# Primary: Eastern US (NIST Gaithersburg, MD)
# Secondary: Western US (NIST Boulder, CO)
$primaryServers = @(
    "time.nist.gov",          # Eastern US - Maryland
    "time-a-g.nist.gov"       # Eastern US - Maryland
)

$secondaryServers = @(
    "time-b-wwv.nist.gov",    # Western US - Colorado  
    "time-c-wwv.nist.gov"     # Western US - Colorado
)

# Combine all servers with flags
# 0x9 = SpecialInterval | Client mode
$allServers = ($primaryServers + $secondaryServers) | ForEach-Object { "$_,0x9" }
$ntpServerList = $allServers -join " "

Write-Host "Configuring time sources: $ntpServerList"

# Stop time service
Stop-Service w32time -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

# Configure with all servers
w32tm /config /manualpeerlist:"$ntpServerList" /syncfromflags:manual /reliable:yes /update

# Start time service
Start-Service w32time
Start-Sleep -Seconds 3

# Force sync
w32tm /resync /force
Start-Sleep -Seconds 5

# Verify configuration
Write-Host "`n=== Configured Time Peers (Geographic Diversity) ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /peers

# Test reachability of each server
Write-Host "`n=== Server Reachability Test ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
foreach ($server in ($primaryServers + $secondaryServers)) {
    $result = Test-Connection -ComputerName $server -Count 1 -Quiet -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
    if ($result) {
        Write-Host "[OK] $server - reachable" -ForegroundColor Green
    } else {
        Write-Host "[WARN] $server - unreachable or slow" -ForegroundColor Yellow
    }
}

# Display current sync status
Write-Host "`n=== Current Synchronization Status ===" -ForegroundColor Yellow
w32tm /query /status

# Document configuration
$docPath = "C:\Windows\System32\config\NTP-Geographic-Diversity.txt"
@"
SC-45.2: Time Source Geographic Diversity Configuration
========================================================

Primary Region: Eastern US (Maryland)
- time.nist.gov
- time-a-g.nist.gov

Secondary Region: Western US (Colorado)
- time-b-wwv.nist.gov
- time-c-wwv.nist.gov

Failover Behavior:
Windows Time Service automatically fails over to secondary
sources if primary sources become unreachable.

Configured: $(Get-Date -Format 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
"@ | Out-File -FilePath $docPath -Encoding UTF8

Write-Host "`nConfiguration documented at: $docPath" -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "`n[SC-45.2] Geographic diversity configuration complete" -ForegroundColor Green
